## R Markdown

This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see <http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com>.

When you click the **Knit** button a document will be generated that includes both content as well as the output of any embedded R code chunks within the document. You can embed an R code chunk like this:

```{r cars}
summary(cars)
```

## Including Plots

You can also embed plots, for example:

```{r pressure, echo=FALSE}
plot(pressure)
```

Note that the `echo = FALSE` parameter was added to the code chunk to prevent printing of the R code that generated the plot.

```{r}
sexo_Vector <- c("Male", "Female", "Female", "Male", "Male")

sexo_factor <- factor(sexo_Vector)
sexo_factor

animals_vector <- c("Abeja","Elephant", "Giraffe", "Donkey", "Horse", "Burro")
animals_vector

class(animals_vector)

animals_factor <- factor(animals_vector)
animals_factor


temperatura_vector <- c("High", "Medium", "Low", "High", "Low")
temperatura_vector

temperatura_factor <- factor(temperatura_vector, order=TRUE, levels = c("Low", "Medium", "High"))
temperatura_factor

survey_vector <- c("M", "F", "F", "M", "M")
survey_vector

survey_factor <- factor(survey_vector)
survey_factor

levels(survey_factor) <- c("Female", "Male")
survey_factor

survey_vector <- c("M", "F", "F", "M", "M")
survey_vector

levels(survey_factor) <- c("Female", "Male")
survey_factor
summary(survey_vector)
summary(survey_factor)

male <- survey_vector[1]
male

female <-survey_vector[2]
female 


male > female

#Factores Ordenados

speed_vector <- c("medium", "slow", "slow", "medium", "fast")
speed_vector

speed_factor <- factor(speed_vector, ordered = TRUE, levels = c("slow", "medium", "fast"))
speed_factor

summary(speed_vector)
summary(speed_factor)

da2 <- speed_factor[2]
da2

da5 <- speed_factor[5]
da5

da2>da5
```
